articles.title: Adjectives, Pronouns and Adverbs
body: h: The Adjectives â€“ Gli aggettivi
Adjectives are words that describe a person or a thing and generally, in Italian, come after nouns.
In order to use adjectives correctly in their singular and plural form, use the same logic as for the nouns:
@table:8
Adjectives always agree with nouns:
@table:9
The adjective â€œBELLOâ€ works like a determinative article when it comes before a noun:
h: The Possessive Adjectives â€“ Gli aggettivi possessivi
Possessive adjectives indicate who the object belongs to or specify the relation among person:
@table:10
They always comes with the article
h: Exception
Not with family members (except for â€œloroâ€):
In the speaking language, we often use expressions like â€œi miei, i tuoi, i suoiâ€ instead of â€œi miei genitori, i tuoi genitori, i suoi genitoriâ€:

Adjectives come with nouns and they agree with them, meanwhile, adverbs specify or modify the meaning of other grammar elements and they usually go with verbs, adjectives and other adverbs and they are invariable.
Please check these phrases comparing adjectives and adverbs:
@table:11
h: The adverbs â€“ Gli avverbi
Adverbs are used to describe and specify a verb, an adjective, another adverb, or a whole phrase ( the adjective that describes a noun or a pronoun is different) and they are invariable:
Adverbs can have different meanings, for example:
Some other examples: ieri, oggi, domani, dopo domani, poi, giÃ , tardi, presto, spesso, talvolta, subito, finora, adesso, sempre, mai, normalmente.
Some other examples: poco, molto/parecchio/tanto, alquanto/abbastanza/piuttosto, piÃ¹ o meno, altrettanto, appena, quanto, per niente.

Some other examples: bene-male, meglio-peggio, insieme, volentieri, apposta, alla svelta (=di corsa, di fretta), ad alta voce/a bassa voce, allâ€™improvviso (=improvvisamente), per scherzo â€“ sul serio, per caso (= casualmente), cosÃ¬, forte, veloce, dritto-storto.
Some other examples: qui/qua, sopra, sotto, dentro, fuori, lontano, vicino, davanti, dietro, via, intorno.
Some adverbs come directly from an adjective and we can form them in this way:
h: Indefinite adjectives â€“ Gli aggettivi indefiniti
Indefinite adjectives indicate a non-specified or unknown person/object to the speaker.
Some of them are invariable and are used only in the singular form, like: â€œqualcheâ€, â€œqualsiasiâ€ o â€œqualunqueâ€/â€ogniâ€:
*when you want to express the same meaning in the plural form, you use: â€œalcuni/alcuneâ€:
h: Indefinite pronouns â€“ I pronomi indefiniti
Some indefinite pronouns are only pronouns, used in the singular form.
Qualcosa (It is unchanged)
Chiunque (it is invariable and it is always followed by a subjunctive)
Qualcuno-a/Uno-a/Ognuno-a (they have a feminine and masculine form)
Niente/Nulla (they have the same meaning, they are invariable and we need to put the negation before the verb)
h: Indefinite adjective, pronouns and adverbs â€“ Aggettivi, pronomi e avverbi indefiniti
Some indefinite can be both adjectives, pronouns (they can be variable) and adverbs (they are always invariable):
Alcuno*: adjective or pronoun, when it comes before the noun, it behaves the same way as the indefinite article:
*It is also used in the singular form, only in negative sentences or after â€œsenzaâ€:
Certo: adjective or pronoun. If itâ€™s singular, it is forerun by an indefinite article, if itâ€™s plural there is no article:
Quale: adjective and pronoun:
Altro: adjective and pronoun:
Poco: adjective, pronoun or adverb:
Molto/Parecchio/Tanto: adjective, pronoun or adverb:
Troppo: adjective, pronoun or adverb:
Ciascuno: adjective or pronoun, always in the singular. As for â€œalcunoâ€, when it comes before the noun it behaves like a indefinite article:
Tutto: when is an adjective, it is followed by a definite article. It can also be a pronoun:

Nessuno: adjective and pronoun, always in the singular. As for â€œalcunoâ€ when it comes before the verb it behaves like an indefinite article. As for â€œNienteâ€ or â€œNullaâ€, it needs the negation before the verb:

body: h: Definite Articles â€“ Gli articoli determinativi
Italian articles identify the gender and number of nouns; they can be masculine or feminine, singular or plural.
In Italian, we have 2 feminine definite articles for the singular form and 1 for the plural form:Â
@table:0
Here are some examples:

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
The masculine definite articles in Italian are 3 for the singular form and 2 for the plural form:
@table:1
Here are some examples:

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
Definite articles are used:
To indicate specific people or objects

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With possessive adjectives and pronouns

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With abstract and general nouns, including colours

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With parts of the body and clothes

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With dates, *if the day of the week is not mentioned before

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With times or other expressions of time

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With the days of the weeks to show habitual actions

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With physical descriptions when the verb â€œavereâ€ (to have) is used

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With titles and qualifications used with names

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
With most geographical names, *except for city names and when the prepositions â€œinâ€ or â€œdiâ€ come before feminine singular geographical names

! Definite articles are not used:

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)

With city names, *although there are some exceptions such as La Spezia, Lâ€™Aquila, Lâ€™Avana, Il Cairo, La Mecca

h: Indefinite Articles â€“ Gli articoli indeterminativi
Indefinite articles are used to introduce someone or something new, not previously mentioned; or to talk about someone or something in a more general and undefined way.
Just as with the definite articles, in Italian there are 2 feminine indefinite articles for the singular form and 1 for the plural form:
@table:2
Here are some examples:

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
And for the masculine form, there are 2Â indefinite articles for the singular form and 2 for the plural form:
@table:3
! Pay attention: with indefinite articles an APOSTROPHE is used only with FEMININE nouns (eg. â€œunâ€™amicaâ€) and NOT with MASCULINE ones (eg. â€œun amicoâ€)
Here are some examples for the masculine form:

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
Indefinite articles are used for:
People, animals, or things that are not known by the person speaking

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
Undefined people, animals or things

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
Parts of the body (of which there are more than one)

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
h: Noun and Gender (Masculine and feminine) â€“ Il nome e il genere (maschile e femminile)
Nouns are words that refer to a person or a thing and they can be masculine or feminine, singular or plural.
Singular nouns ending in â€“ O are masculine, and change to end in -I in the plural form:
@table:4
Singular nouns ending in â€“ A are feminine, and change to end in -E in the plural form:
@table:5

Singular nouns ending in -E can be either masculine or feminine: there is no special rule to help identify them, only studying and practicing them!
However, the plural form always ends in â€“ I (masculine) and -e (feminine), as shown in these examples:
@table:6
@table:7
Some exceptions to the rules:

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
Nouns that have been taken from other languages or that end in an accent are invariable, and so we just change the article in the plural form:

-La borsa (The bag) â€“ Le borse (The bags);La finestra (The window) â€“ Le finestre (The windows);La porta (The door) â€“ Le porte (The doors);Lâ€™ora (The hour) â€“ Le ore (The hours);Lâ€™alba (The dawn) â€“ Le albe (The dawns);Lâ€™aula (The classroom) â€“ Le aule (The classrooms)
!PAY ATTENTION: to change a noun from singular to plural, always remember to change both the article and the ending!

body: h: Majority and minority comparatives â€“ Comparativi di maggioranza e minoranza
In order to compare two or more elements, we normally use piÃ¹ di (more than +) for the comparisons of majority and meno di (less than -) for the comparisons of minority:
â€œpiÃ¹/meno + adjective + di + nouns /Â personal pronounsâ€

+ Martina Ã¨ piÃ¹ simpatica di Luisa

+ Il cane Ã¨ piÃ¹ fedele del gatto
+ Il computer Ã¨ piÃ¹ moderno della macchina da scrivere

â€“ Luisa Ã¨ meno simpatica di Martina
â€“ Io sono meno alto di Luca
â€“ Il gatto Ã¨ meno fedele del cane
â€“ La macchina da scrivere Ã¨ meno moderna del computer
We normally use piÃ¹ che (more than) or meno che (less than) to compare two or more elements belonging to all the other cases:
â€œpiÃ¹/meno + adjective + che + adjectives, verbs,Â adverbs, prepositionsâ€

-Luca Ã¨ piÃ¹/meno alto che bello;Il computer Ã¨ piÃ¹/meno utile che difficile da usare;Mi piace piÃ¹/meno cucinare che mangiare;Giocare a tennis Ã¨ piÃ¹/meno divertente che studiare;Il clima in Sicilia Ã¨ piÃ¹/meno mite che in Lombardia;Anna Ã¨ piÃ¹/meno gentile con Tatiana che con me;Mio fratello Ã¨ piÃ¹/meno affezionato a mio padre che a mia madre
h: Comparative of quantity â€“ Comparativo di quantitÃ
We express comparative of quantity with the construction:
â€œPiÃ¹ â€¦ cheâ€
-Leggo piÃ¹ giornali che libri;In quel paese ci sono piÃ¹ poveri che ricchi;Bevo piÃ¹ tÃ¨ che caffÃ¨;Lucia ha piÃ¹ vestiti che scarpe
h: Comparative of equality â€“ Comparativo di uguaglianza
When we want to express the same quantity, we use the construction:
â€œTanto â€¦ quantoâ€ / â€œCosÃ¬ â€¦ comeâ€
-Quel cane Ã¨ fedele quanto un gatto;Luca e Mattia sono studiosi quanto noi;Pietro Ã¨ alto come Leo;Lucia Ã¨ magra come me
Sometimes adjectives can be forerun by tanto, if with the second element of comparison we use quanto:
-Leonardo Ã¨ (tanto) grasso quanto basso;Il computer Ã¨ (tanto) utile quanto costoso;Marta Ã¨ (tanto) timida quanto Lisa
Otherwise, adjectives can be forerun by cosÃ¬, if with the second element of comparison we use come:
-Marta Ã¨ (cosÃ¬) timida come Lisa;Voi siete (cosÃ¬) giovani come noi;Gli studenti della tua classe sono (cosÃ¬) diligenti come noi
h: The relative superlative â€“ Il superlativo relativo
The relative superlative indicates a person or thingâ€™s quality expressed to the maximum or the minimum level, in relation to a group.
The relative superlative of majority is expressed by il piÃ¹ di,Â meanwhile the relative superlative of minority is expressed by il meno di.
â€œ(Article) + noun + piÃ¹ /meno + adjective + (di/fra-tra)â€

-Questo Ã¨ il piÃ¹ bel libro che abbia mai letto;Luca Ã¨ il ragazzo piÃ¹ simpatico che conosca;La torta della nonna Ã¨ la piÃ¹ buona che abbia mai mangiato

The absolute superlative indicates the quality expressed to the maximum and absolute grade, independent to any comparison:

articles.title: Impersonal and Passive Forms
body: h: The Impersonal Form â€“ La forma impersonale

Impersonal form expresses general actions, common to lots of people.
All the verbs, both transitive and intransitive, have impersonal forms.
To form it, we use:
si or uno + verb at the 3rd singular person

-A Pasqua si mangia lâ€™uovo di cioccolato;In biblioteca si legge, si studia e si parla a bassa voce;In montagna si scia, si cammina e si gioca con la neve;In classe uno legge ad alta voce;A Firenze uno va per musei
-Stasera diluvia, stiamo a casa;Oggi non piove, ma grandina;Sulle Alpi nevica giÃ ;Fa caldo o fa freddo in autunno a Firenze?;Nel fine settimana farÃ  bello, possiamo fare una passeggiata
With some verbs like essere (to be), diventare (to become), sembrare (to seem), restare (to remain), we use the plural adjective:
Si + essere/diventare/sembrare/restare (3rd singular person) + plural adjective
-Quando si Ã¨ contenti, si lavora meglio;Se si studia molto, si diventa bravi;Si sembra pazzi quando si  Ã¨ innamorati;Si resta attoniti dopo avere visto un incidente
-Uno Ã¨ stanco dopo una settimana di lavoro;Uno diventa matto se fa due lavori
h: Impersonal form of the reflexive verbs â€“ La forma impersonale dei verbi riflessivi
For the impersonal form of the reflexive verbs we have 2 options as well:
Ci or uno + si + verb (3rd singular person)
-Sposarsi â†’ ci si sposa / uno si sposa;Vestirsi â†’ ci si veste/ uno si veste;Alzarsi â†’ ci si alza/ uno si alza
Note:

-La domenica mattina ci si sveglia tardi = La domenica mattina uno si sveglia tardi;In vacanza ci si rilassa = In vacanza uno si rilassa;Quando si guarda un film comico, ci si diverte = Uno si diverte quando guarda un film comico
h: Impersonal form in the Past Perfect â€“ La forma impersonale al passato prossimo

To be able to use the right impersonal form in the Past Perfect, you need to remember the right auxiliary, essere (â€œto beâ€) or avere (â€œto haveâ€).
Remember that if you use essere the verbs agrees with the subject, so that it can be singular, plural, feminine or masculine.
Si + Ã¨ + Past Participle
Verbs which need avere as auxiliary in the Past Perfect (transitive verbs):
-LEGGERE â†’ Si legge â†’ Si Ã¨ letto molti libri;MANGIARE â†’ Si mangia â†’ Si Ã¨ mangiato molto durante le feste;STUDIARE â†’ Si studia â†’ Si Ã¨ studiato molto prima dellâ€™esame
Verbs which need essere as auxiliary in the Past Perfect (verbs of movement, verbs of state or change, reflexive verbs):

-ANDARE â†’ Si va â†’ Si Ã¨ andati/e per musei;DIVENTARE â†’ Si diventa â†’ Si Ã¨ diventati/e matti/e a cercare il regalo giusto per Giulia;SVEGLIARSI â†’ Ci si sveglia â†’ Ci si Ã¨ svegliati/e presto;ALLENARSI â†’ Ci si allena â†’ Ci si Ã¨ allenati/e molto in vista della finale
h: The Passive Form â€“ La forma passiva
Only the transitive verbs, the ones which answer to the question â€œwho or what?â€, have an active (when the subject does the action) and a passive voice (when the subject is acted upon by the verb).
Moreover, in the passive voice, the doer of the action can be mentioned and so it can be introduced by the preposition da (from/by), otherwise we can also avoid it.
We can build it in several ways, according to the tense of the phrase:
-essere (to be) + past participle;venire (to come) + past participle;si + 3rd singular or plural person;andare (to go) + past participle

Active: Lâ€™insegnante spiega la grammatica.
Passive: La grammatica Ã¨/viene spiegata dallâ€™insegnante.

Active: Lâ€™insegnante ha spiegato la grammatica.
Passive: La grammatica Ã¨ stata spiegata dallâ€™insegnante.
Look at the difference: impersonal form â€œsiâ€ has only a singular form, meanwhile passive form â€œsiâ€ can have both singular or plural object!
â€œSiâ€ as passive voice:

Singular object: A Firenze si studia la lingua italiana. / A Natale si mangia molto.
Plural object: A Firenze si visitano i musei. / A Natale si mangiano tanti dolci.
h: Passive form with the verb essere (to be) â€“ La forma passiva con il verbo essere
The construction essere (to be) + past participle can be used with all the verbal tenses, both simple and compound tenses.
Essere conjugates at the same verbal tense of the active sentence and remember that the Past Participle agrees.
Moreover, with this construction, the person or thing that does the action can be specified, and it is forerun by the preposition da.

-La polizia controlla i documenti delle persone sospette.

-Botticelli ha dipinto questo quadro.

-I suoi contemporanei soprannominavano Lorenzo deâ€™ Medici â€œil Magnificoâ€.

-Zubin Mehta dirigerÃ  il prossimo concerto.

h: Passive form with the verb venire (to come) â€“ La forma passiva con il verbo venire
The construction is made with venire (to come) + past participle.

This construction can only be used with simple tenses (Present, Imperfect, Simple Future..) and it can not be used with compound tenses (Past Perfect, Future Perfect, Pluperfect..). Always remember that the Past Participle agrees.
As for the essere construction, the verb venire needs to be conjugated in the same tense as the active sentence.

-La polizia controlla i documenti delle persone sospette.
Passive ğŸ¡’ I documenti delle persone sospettate vengono controllati dalla polizia;Il sole abbronza la pelle dei contadini.

-I suoi contemporanei soprannominavano Lorenzo deâ€™ Medici â€œil Magnificoâ€

h: Passive form with the verb andare (to go) â€“ La forma passiva con il verbo andare
The construction is made with andare + past participle and it has a particular meaning of obligation or need:
-A che ora vanno portati i ragazzi alla partita? (= devono essere portati);Questo film va visto (= deve essere visto);Il biglietto va timbrato prima di salire sul treno (= deve essere timbrato)
This construction can be used only with simple tenses.

-Il libro va studiato per lâ€™esame.
Passive ğŸ¡’ Il registro delle presenze va aggiornato ogni giorno.

-Andrebbe fatto un corso di aggiornamento per gli impiegati.
Passive ğŸ¡’ In comune andrebbe assunta unâ€™altra segretaria.
With this construction, we can also specify the person or thing that carries out the action and it is forerun by the preposition da:

-Tutti dovrebbero fare la raccolta differenziata.
Passive ğŸ¡’ La raccolta differenziata andrebbe fatta da tutti.
h:
h: The â€œpassivizingâ€ si â€“ Il si passivante

The construction is:
si + 3rd person singular or plural of the verb.
The sentence has a general meaning (the people, everyone, everybody):
-In Italia a Natale si mangia il panettone.;In Italia si mangiano gli spaghetti.;Internet si usa spesso per lavoro.;Si spendono molti soldi per Natale.

Pay attention: if the passive subject is singular, the verb needs to be conjugated in the 3rd person singular; if the passive subject is plural, the verb needs to be conjugated in the 3rd person plural:
-La medicina si prende dopo i pasti.;Le medicine si prendono dopo i pasti.;Il regalo si apre il giorno del compleanno.;I regali si aprono il giorno del compleanno.

This construction can be used with all the tenses, both simple and compound tenses.
If we use it with compound tenses, we always need to use essere (to be) as the auxiliary:
-Quando si sarÃ  capito come il direttore vuole organizzare la riunione, potremo scrivere il programma.
With this construction, the person or thing that does the action is not mentioned.

-Active form: Marco saluta Claudia.
Correct passive form: Claudia Ã¨ salutata da Marco.
 Error:  Claudia si bacia da Marco.;Active form: La mamma bacia il papÃ .
Correct passive form: Il papÃ  Ã¨ baciato dalla mamma.
 Error: Il papÃ  si bacia dalla mamma.
The following construction gives the sentence an impersonal meaning: therefore, we often use it in commercial adds, adding â€œsiâ€ at the end of the verb:
-Vendesi auto usata (si vende);Affittasi appartamento in centro (si affitta)
h: Modal Verbs in the Passive Form â€“ La forma passiva dei verbi modali
With modal verbs dovere (to have to), potere (to be able), volere (to want), we use the construction:
essere (to be) + past participle
PRESENT TENSE  WITH â€œPOTEREâ€

Active: I residenti possono usare il parcheggio.
Passive: Il parcheggio puÃ² essere usato dai residenti.

Active: Gli studenti possono ritirare i diplomi in segreteria.
Passive: I diplomi possono essere ritirati in segreteria.
PRESENT TENSE WITH â€œDOVEREâ€
When dovere expresses a requirement or need, in passive form we can also use the verb andare (to go):

Active: Il bambino deve prendere la medicina alla stessa ora.
Passive: La medicina deve essere presa alla stessa ora / La medicina va presa alla stessa ora.

Active: Tutti devono pagare le tasse.
Passive: Le tasse devono essere pagate da tutti / Le tasse vanno pagate.
